title: How to Wrap a Wedding Cake

steps.headline: Remove any flowers or decorations on the cake.
steps.description: These decorations can interfere with the wrapping and freezing of the cake. Place the flowers or decorations on a separate tray lined with wax paper. You can then wrap and freeze them separately if you want to preserve them. Most wedding cake decorations are made out of sugar paste, which does not go bad. You can still wrap the decorations in plastic wrap and freeze them on a tray to be safe.

steps.headline: Place the cake in the freezer for at least 2-3 hours.
steps.description: Pre-freezing the cake will allow the icing to set and ensure you do not ruin the icing when you wrap up the cake. Make sure the cake is not touching any items in the freezer so it can set properly. You can put the cake in the fridge if your freezer is full, but it will take longer for the cake to set. Leave it in the fridge overnight to be sure the icing has set.

steps.headline: Remove the frozen cake and place it on a plate.
steps.description: Once the cake has set, take it out and place it on a plate or a flat serving dish that can go in the freezer. This will make it easier for you to wrap the cake properly.

steps.headline: Wrap the cake tightly in 3-4 layers of plastic wrap.
steps.description: Wrap the cake as tight as you can without damaging the icing. Use several layers of plastic wrap to keep moisture out and ensure the cake freezes well. Do not use aluminum foil to wrap the cake, as this can cause freezer burn.

steps.headline: Place the cake in a cake box and wrap the box with plastic.
steps.description: If you have the box the cake came in, put the cake back in the box and wrap it in 3-4 layers of plastic wrap. Use tape to secure the ends of the plastic wrap on the box so it is well sealed. Check that there are no holes or gaps in the box, as you do not want the cake exposed to the cold air in the freezer. This can cause it to dry out.

steps.headline: Put the cake in an airtight container if you do not have a cake box.
steps.description: Place the wrapped cake in a plastic or glass container with a resealable, airtight lid. Make sure the container is freezer safe and large enough to fit the cake. The cake should sit snugly in the container.

steps.headline: Label or mark the cake so you can identify it.
steps.description: Use a decoration from your wedding like a ribbon or card and tape it on the cake so you know what it is. You can also use a label to write the date you froze the cake.

steps.headline: Place it in the freezer to preserve it.
steps.description: Position the cake on the bottom or on a flat, even section of the freezer. Try not to place next to items with strong odors or smells, such as frozen onions or fish. Make sure the cake is not being touched by other items so the icing does not get damaged. Keep in mind certain cakes will freeze and last better than others. Chocolate, hazelnut, almond, and carrot cakes will stay moist and likely retain their texture when frozen. White cake and cake with fresh fruit or whipped cream fillings may not freeze as well.

steps.headline: Take the cake out of the freezer and place it in the fridge overnight.
steps.description: When you are ready to dig into your preserved wedding cake, put it on a shelf in your fridge to defrost. Try to put it on its own shelf or area so it does not pick up any smells from other foods.

steps.headline: Leave the cake on the counter at room temperature for 5-6 hours.
steps.description: Remove the cake from the box or container it is in and let it come to room temperature. This will allow the cake to thaw properly all the way through. Leave the cake out on the day you plan to serve it so it is ready to eat in the evening.

steps.headline: Remove the wrapping from the thawed cake.
steps.description: After the cake has reached room temperature all the way through, gently peel off the layers of plastic wrap. Dispose of the wrapping and slice the cake so it is ready to serve and eat. Most wedding cakes are safe to eat if they are properly wrapped, frozen, and thawed within 1-2 years. Eating a wedding cake after 2 years in the freezer could put you at risk of food poisoning so plan to have the cake sooner than later to be safe.

text: Chilling the Cake Remove any flowers or decorations on the cake. These decorations can interfere with the wrapping and freezing of the cake. Place the flowers or decorations on a separate tray lined with wax paper. You can then wrap and freeze them separately if you want to preserve them. Most wedding cake decorations are made out of sugar paste, which does not go bad. You can still wrap the decorations in plastic wrap and freeze them on a tray to be safe. Place the cake in the freezer for at least 2-3 hours. Pre-freezing the cake will allow the icing to set and ensure you do not ruin the icing when you wrap up the cake. Make sure the cake is not touching any items in the freezer so it can set properly. You can put the cake in the fridge if your freezer is full, but it will take longer for the cake to set. Leave it in the fridge overnight to be sure the icing has set. Remove the frozen cake and place it on a plate. Once the cake has set, take it out and place it on a plate or a flat serving dish that can go in the freezer. This will make it easier for you to wrap the cake properly. Wrapping the Cake Wrap the cake tightly in 3-4 layers of plastic wrap. Wrap the cake as tight as you can without damaging the icing. Use several layers of plastic wrap to keep moisture out and ensure the cake freezes well. Do not use aluminum foil to wrap the cake, as this can cause freezer burn. Place the cake in a cake box and wrap the box with plastic. If you have the box the cake came in, put the cake back in the box and wrap it in 3-4 layers of plastic wrap. Use tape to secure the ends of the plastic wrap on the box so it is well sealed. Check that there are no holes or gaps in the box, as you do not want the cake exposed to the cold air in the freezer. This can cause it to dry out. Put the cake in an airtight container if you do not have a cake box. Place the wrapped cake in a plastic or glass container with a resealable, airtight lid. Make sure the container is freezer safe and large enough to fit the cake. The cake should sit snugly in the container. Label or mark the cake so you can identify it. Use a decoration from your wedding like a ribbon or card and tape it on the cake so you know what it is. You can also use a label to write the date you froze the cake. Place it in the freezer to preserve it. Position the cake on the bottom or on a flat, even section of the freezer. Try not to place next to items with strong odors or smells, such as frozen onions or fish. Make sure the cake is not being touched by other items so the icing does not get damaged. Keep in mind certain cakes will freeze and last better than others. Chocolate, hazelnut, almond, and carrot cakes will stay moist and likely retain their texture when frozen. White cake and cake with fresh fruit or whipped cream fillings may not freeze as well. Unwrapping the Cake Take the cake out of the freezer and place it in the fridge overnight. When you are ready to dig into your preserved wedding cake, put it on a shelf in your fridge to defrost. Try to put it on its own shelf or area so it does not pick up any smells from other foods. Leave the cake on the counter at room temperature for 5-6 hours. Remove the cake from the box or container it is in and let it come to room temperature. This will allow the cake to thaw properly all the way through. Leave the cake out on the day you plan to serve it so it is ready to eat in the evening. Remove the wrapping from the thawed cake. After the cake has reached room temperature all the way through, gently peel off the layers of plastic wrap. Dispose of the wrapping and slice the cake so it is ready to serve and eat. Most wedding cakes are safe to eat if they are properly wrapped, frozen, and thawed within 1-2 years. Eating a wedding cake after 2 years in the freezer could put you at risk of food poisoning so plan to have the cake sooner than later to be safe.
